summary: This document is an email chain between legal counsel in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, discussing procedural matters related to the public filing of reply briefs and exhibits. The correspondence focuses on conferring about proposed redactions to protect the privacy of victims, third parties, and Assistant U.S. Attorneys, as ordered by Judge Nathan. It reveals the negotiation process between the defense and prosecution regarding what information should remain sealed.

persons.name: GMJetter
persons.context: The sender of the initial email in the chain, attaching a letter intended for filing with the court regarding redactions to reply briefs.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: The judge who issued orders (Dkt. 203, 207) directing the parties to confer on redactions and pretrial disclosure deadlines.

connections.description: Attorney (likely for the defense) is following the court's orders issued by Judge Nathan regarding the filing and redaction of legal briefs.

events.title: Submission of Joint Letter
events.description: The parties submitted a joint letter to the court, which Judge Nathan later ordered to be docketed or have redactions proposed by April 19, 2021.

events.title: Court Order on Redactions
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order (Dkt. 168) adopting proposed redactions to certain exhibits (J and O) to protect privacy interests.

events.title: Filing of Letter on Redactions
events.description: GMJetter indicates intent to file a letter on the court's electronic docket (ECF) regarding the parties' positions on redactions for several reply briefs.

keyFacts: The document is a chain of emails between legal teams negotiating redactions to undocketed reply briefs in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case.

The primary dispute centers on whether to redact names of Assistant U.S. Attorneys (AUSAs), accusers (victims), and other third parties to protect their privacy, with the defense often having no objection to public filing.

The government seeks to keep certain exhibits under seal or redacted, citing a Protective Order and the need to protect victim and third-party privacy, which the defense generally does not oppose but leaves for the government to justify to the court.
Judge Nathan had previously set deadlines and ruled on specific redactions, providing a framework for the parties' discussions.
